bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to R.H. von Ezdorf, February 16, 1916

div1.p: Carter discusses anti-mosquito work and mentions the Rockefeller Foundation.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to R.H. von Ezdorf, February 16, 1916
div1.p: This is a letter of details.

1st: So far as your Chatanooga affair is concerned I told Le-
Prince to tell you I would be very glad for you to take the job1
that it was in no sense any interference with my work, and if it
were I would not care.

2nd: And far more important a thing: I have been think-
ing how valuable--or rather how necessary--LePrince is for plan-
ning and supervising the anti-mosquito work which various places
undertake. Lanette: Crystal City: Emporia and some place near
Vicksburg of which he spoke to me, whose name I forget, are all
doing such work this year and not unlikely he may be needed as
a consultant at Lake and Chicot. If it be practicable to put
someone else with Griffitts would it not be better to simply
give LePrince all the investigations--mainly entomological--this
year of the impounded waters, letting him visit this party as
necessary, and do this other anti-mosquito work, which I think
no one else can do so well as himself. The same, indeed, is true
of the work he would be leaving on the impounded waters.

I do not know that we can get any satisfactory man to go with
Griffitts. I spoke to Kerr about it tentatively. It is a “tri-
lemma:” a/ If money is available he says he could get King.
-2-
who, as the problems are entomological, would be very satisfac-
tory for the work. b/ If it be possible to spare him--Fox--
who wishes to make himself an all-round medical entomologist.
I don't know what he knows about mosquitoes, but he is probably
our highest American on fleas and, if he will take up this work
he can do very much better in it than I would. I think he will
not be available. It was Kerr's suggestion. c/ Nobody. Give
Griffitts authority to employ some bright earnest fellow--like
young Hayne was last year--and two such men--and Lucrinceitce to
visiting and staying with them as much as he could with the oth-
er duties. Possibly he could get some student of entomology--
or local entomologist--who would do quite well. Conradi, Proff
essor of Entomology at the University of South Carolina, could,
I judge, be gotten for $150.00 a month and expenses.

What do you think of the need of LePrince and how much time
would it take at the places that are doing and ingoing to do, work
against mosquitoes? By the way, you might add Georgetown, S. C.
which Hayne is anxious for you to visit and where he says they
are prepared to pay any reasonable amount for anti-malarial work.
The Mayor is a physician.

3rd: I certainly hope you will have good luck--I know you
will take pains--in selecting the most suitable place for your
Rockefeller work. Be sure that you don't take a place where the
difficulties are too great. To explain a less success than Bass'--
no matter if the reasons are good--would not be satisfactory.
I am awfully sorry for the floods in Arkansas and hope they have
not affected the places you have picked out injuriously. Had, it
been possible to have done this work in Mississippi in a place
-3-
where the conditions were as nearly as maybe the same as Bass's,
the comparison would have been more accurate. I know too, that
Leathers is an excellent administrative officer and would have
handled that end--the most difficult one of the problem--well.
Garrison may be the same, but I don't know him so well.

I am sending back your glossary with the names defined by
the Standard Dictionary. I am unquestionably wrong in my “ham-
mock.” I judge that it should more properly be called “raft” or
“mat” although it is called “hammock” in Maryland: Virginia:
North and South Carolina. I think I covered it properly, however,
in my report by the devise I told you. I will add that “marsh”
on the South Atlantic--South Carolina and Georgia--refers only
to salt marsh, which, of course, is a mistack, but a fact. “Pool”
is a technical name (U. S. Engineers) for the water impounded for
navigation above a lock--although it is very large. It rightly
means “a small pond.” “Branch” and “brook” are identical: “A run-
ning stream smaller than a creek.” “Creek” in the United States
needs no definition. It is spread on all our maps. Abroad it
refers exclusively I think to salt water creeks.

About myself: I judge that I will be absent this summer and
have not quite made up my mind on the matter as I could not see
Dr. Gorgas Saturday. He is in Alabama, I think a witness in the
suit for the Alabama Power Co. That is why, in my arrangements
for this year, I have not taken account of my own work. I may
not go, however. Will let you know as soon as it is definitely
settled.

What about our getting the Service to supply certain stations
with LePrince's book? It is very interesting to me because I know
the Isthmus and it has a very large amount of new matter.

I am enclosing also, in accordance with our custom, our re-
port on the Whitney work--the first attempt to utilize the observa-
tions we have made on Impounded waters in the sanitation of a
pond before it is made. It is an extremely difficult proposition.
Please return it to me.

About when will you start the field work--especially the
Rockefeller work?
div1.closer:
Very truly your friend, 2 enclosures.
HRC/LC
